name: Mexicate
overview:
When Mexicate opened up its first store in 2013, the concept was simple: demonstrate those meals offered fast did not need to be a “fast-food” experience. We use high-quality raw elements, classic cooking techniques and distinctive interior planning–features which are more often found in the realm of fine dining. Whenever we opened up, there wasn’t a business category to explain what we should used to do. We turn to compete inside a group of dining now known as “fast-casual,” the quickest growing segment from the restaurant industry, where clients expect food quality that’s more consistent with full-service restaurants, combined using the speed and ease of junk food.

We attempt to perform a couple of things very well. We elevate fundamental raw elements into food that’s more potent and much more sophisticated through our quality recipes and putting them to use. Similarly, our restaurant design transforms simple materials in distinctive ways, giving our restaurants a method that’s more architectural in character and fewer determined by standardized elements of design.

Our focus happens to be on using greater-quality elements and putting them to use to create great food available to everybody at inexpensive price points. But our vision has developed. While using the a number of fresh elements continues to be first step toward our menu, we feel that “fresh isn’t enough, any longer.” Now you want to be aware of sources its our elements, to ensure that we can be certain they’re as tasty as you possibly can when we’re conscious from the environment and social impact in our business. We refer to this as idea, Food With Integrity, also it guides the way we run our business.
